Fig. 5 Fig. 6 TG/DTA profiles of spent Al-15B and spent Al-B-5Sb samples. Ethyl benzene oxidative dehydrogenation to styrene on Al-B and Al-B-Sb catalysts Abdulrahim A. Al-Zahrani Nagaraju Pasupulety ⁎ Muhammad A. Daous Hafedh Driss Arshid M. Ali Sharif F. Zaman Lachezar A. Petrov ⁎ Chemical and Materials Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, King Abdulaziz University, P.O. Box 80204, Jeddah 21589, Saudi Arabia Chemical and Materials Engineering Department Faculty of Engineering King Abdulaziz University P.O. Box 80204 Jeddah 21589 Saudi Arabia ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Alumina (Al), alumina-boron (Al-15B), alumina-boron-antimony (Al-B-Sb) and alumina-antimony (Al-15Sb) catalysts were synthesized by sol-gel method using ethanol as a solvent and ammonia gas as a gel forming agent. These catalysts were studied for the dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene (EB) to styrene in the presence of oxygen and steam. The reaction was carried out in the temperature range of 450-500 °C with EB contact time 0.54 gcat.s/cm3. The synthesized catalysts were characterized by using N2-physisorption, XRD, XPS, TEM-HRTEM-EDS and NH3-TPD-mass spectral analysis techniques. At 475 °C, only 58% of styrene selectivity with 32% of EB conversion was observed on Al. Addition of 15 mol.% of B to Al significantly enhanced the selectivity of styrene to 94% with 46% EB conversion at 475 °C. Addition of 15 mol.% Sb to Al reduced the EB conversion (38%) and styrene selectivity (75%) compared to Al-15B catalyst. Interestingly, small amount of Sb (5 mol.%) addition to Al-B improved the EB conversion to 52.5% with 92% of styrene selectivity at 475 °C. The acid sites of weak and moderate strength were increased in Al-15B catalyst compared to Al. Boron played a dual role as Al densification suppressing agent and to some extent deposited on the surface of Al which improved the styrene selectivity. However, small amount of Sb addition to Al-15B not only retained weak and moderate strength acid sites of Al-B but also generated acid sites of Sb which led to the formation of N2O and NO during NH3-TPD-mass analysis. Hence, the styrene yield (48.8%) was improved on Al-B-5Sb compared to Al-15B catalyst (43%). It is noteworthy that Al-15B and Al-B-5Sb catalysts were stable for more than 60h of reaction. Keywords Ethylbenzene (EB) Styrene Oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) Al-B catalyst 1 Introduction Styrene is an important industrial aromatic monomer mainly used for production of polystyrene and styrene-butadiene co-polymers. Direct dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene (EB) to styrene accounts for 85% of commercial production. The reaction is carried out in the vapor phase using potassium-iron oxide catalyst. The reaction is endothermic, and can be accomplished either adiabatically or isothermally. Typical reaction temperatures used in commercial reactors are up to 620 °C. The initial reaction mixture contains EB and in excess steam. The EB conversion is between 55 and 60% and styrene selectivity varies between 90 and 95% [1]. The use of steam as a diluent is an essential part of this process as it serves several functions: delivers heat for the reaction; improves EB conversion by lowering its partial pressure and prevents deactivation by coke formation [2]. However, this conventional route suffers from several disadvantages such as intensive energy consumption and rapid coking [1]. The oxidative dehydrogenation [ODH] is considered as a promising alternative process since the removal of hydrogen by the formation of water converts the overall reaction to an exothermal and irreversible [3]. Further ODH process can be operated at lower temperatures (450–500 °C) and the EB conversion would not be equilibrium limited [4]. Alumina is used in many studies as a catalyst for ODH of EB to styrene. The moderate acidic surface of alumina played a crucial role in its activity for ODH of EB. It was also reported that the surface coke on the alumina played a significant role for obtaining higher styrene yield with lower CO2 formation [5]. Another way to control the acidity of alumina is the use of high temperature calcinations of the sample. The high temperature heat treatment can reduce the amount of surface OH groups on alumina. At temperatures higher than 800 °C most of the hydroxyl groups in alumina surface can be removed as water. Hence, on the surface, alumina oxygen vacancies are formed which behave as strong Lewis acid sites [5]. Preparation of catalyst by impregnation of H3BO3 on alumina leads to the formation of sample with increased surface acidity. Under similar ODH of EB reaction conditions, the catalytic activity and selectivity of B/Al impregnated catalyst found to be higher than alumina sample. However, the observed coke formation was high on this sample [2,5,6]. It was also found that the addition of B2O3 to TiO2–ZrO2 has improved the acidic strength and number of acidic sites on the sample surface [7]. It is well known fact, that Sb promotes the catalytic activity and selectivity of oxide catalysts for ODH of EB. Sb is also an important additive particularly for the formation and stabilization of highly dispersed V2O5 species on Al2O3 employed in ODH of EB [8]. Sb addition to V showed a lower coking activity in oxidative dehydrogenation of light paraffins [9]. An US patent (US 2010/0179358A1) was granted to our group in 2010 for Al-B catalyst synthesis by sol-gel method [10]. The patented method was based on using ethanol as a solvent and gaseous ammonia as a gel formation agent. Al-B samples prepared by using this method have very high surface area (290 m2 g−1) and showed good catalytic activity in ODH of EB. The present paper explores the impact of the compositions of Al based samples with B and Sb on their surface acidity and its resultant effect on styrene yield in ODH of EB. Further, long term catalyst stability was examined on the best Al-B-Sb compositions. Spent catalyst coke formations were investigated through TG-DT analysis. 2 Catalyst preparation All the catalysts were prepared by sol-gel method [10]. Aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3.9H2O) solution was treated with ammonia gas for the synthesis of alumina. 2.1 Preparation of Al-15B and Al-B-Sb catalysts 73.6 g of aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3.9H2O) was dissolved in 196 cm3 of ethanol and the resulting solution was stirred for one hour at 45 °C. Boric acid solution was prepared by dissolving 2.42 g of boric acid in 25 cm3 of distilled water under continuous stirring at 100 °C. Further, boric acid solution was added to aluminum nitrate solution under continues stirring. The resultant white turbid suspension was stirred for 1 h at 65 °C. The suspension was cooled down to room temperature by passing ammonia gas (99.99%) through it at a flow rate of 10 cm3 min−1. The suspension turned into a thick white gel at pH = 6.2. To this gel, 100 cm3 of ethanol was added and the system was left for overnight refluxing at 90 °C under continuous stirring. Finally, the obtained gel was dried in a preheated oven at 120 °C for 3 h under static air. For Al-B-5Sb, 2.85 g of SbCl3 was dissolved in 50 cm3 of ethanol. This SbCl3 solution was added to the alumina-boron solution under continuous stirring at 65 °C. Identical procedure was followed to synthesize Al-B-10Sb and Al-15Sb catalysts. All the dried samples were calcined at 600 °C for 20 h in static air. The numerical number in Al-B and Al-Sb samples indicate the mole percentage loading of B or Sb in Al. 2.2 Experimental procedure for catalyst testing The pre and post reactor zones were filled with quartz beads. Catalytic tests were performed in the temperature range of 450–500 °C at W/F = 0.54 g.s/cm3 (STP) with respect to EB flow. The molar ratio of oxygen to EB was 0.9 and H2O to EB was 4.The feed composition with volume percentage of 7.8% EB, 7.0% oxygen, 31.2% steam and 54.0% helium was studied under the reaction conditions. All the connections leading to and leaving from the reactor was maintained at 180 °C to avoid the condensation of liquid products and water. Blank tests were also performed under similar reaction conditions. The product stream composition was analyzed by HP 6890 GC equipped with FID and TCD with single oven programming. Non hydrocarbons of 1ml injection volume (O2, CO and CO2) were analyzed by TCD equipped with Molseive and Porapak N columns with 10 port GSV control column reversal technique. Hydrocarbons of 0.25 ml injection volume (methane, ethane, ethylene, benzene, toluene, ethyl benzene and styrene) were analyzed using FID equipped with Silcoport WAW column. GC was calibrated with standard gases (certified gases from AHM, Saudi Arabia) and analytical grade liquids. The overall carbon balance was close to 98% by GC analysis. EB and oxygen conversion, product selectivity (SP) and styrene yield (Yst) was calculated by following equations. % Conversion = moles consumed moles in the feed × 100 % SP = moles of product moles of EB consumed × 100 % Styrene yield = EB Conversion × Styrene selectivity 2.3 Catalyst characterization The catalysts were characterized by N2-physisorption, XRD, XPS, TEM-HRTEM-EDS and NH3-TPD-mass spectral analysis techniques. The BET surface area and pore size results (using DFT method) of Al-B and Al-B-Sb samples were obtained using Nova Station Quantachrome (USA) adsorption equipment at liquid nitrogen temperature after out gassing the samples at 200 °C under vacuum for 2 h. The X-ray diffractograms of the Al-B and Al-B-Sb samples were obtained on a EQUINOX 1000 Inel XRD instrument using Co Kα =1.7902Å with X-ray source generator settings at 40kV and 30mA with real time acquisition over 2θ from 10 to 110°. XPS results of Al-B, Al-Sb and Al-B-Sb samples were collected on SPECS GmbH high vacuum multi-technique surface analysis system equipped with Mg Kα 1253.6 eV X-ray source. The reported binding energy values are based on C 1s 284.8 eV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), High resolution TEM images and energy dispersive x-ray analysis (EDS) of Al-B-Sb samples were collected on a Technai 200 kV D1234 Super Twin microscope with camera length of 97 cm. Selected area electron diffractograms (SAED) analysis was performed using Diffraction ring profiler 1.7. Temperature programmed ammonia desorption (NH3-TPD) experiments were conducted on ChemBET Pulsar automatic chemisorption analyzer (Quantachrome Instrument). The mass spectral analysis was performed using ThermoStarTM GSD 320 quad core mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer, Germany). The typical mass fragments input were as follows: m/z = 16 (-NH2), m/z = 17 (NH3), m/z = 18 (H2O), m/z = 30 (NO) and m/z = 44(N2O). In a typical experiment, catalyst sample of 100 mg was placed in a quartz cell and pretreated at 200 °C in He flow (10 cm3 min−1) for 2 h. Subsequently, the temperature of the sample was brought to 50 °C and saturated with 5 vol.% NH3-N2 for 1 h. Eventually, the sample was flushed with He flow (10 cm3 min−1) for 1 h. Desorption of probe gas was performed over the temperature range of 50–550 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C min−1.The desorption stream was analyzed simultaneously using a TCD and mass spectral detector by means of an automated split valve. TG-DTG analysis was carried out using a TG-DTG thermal analyser (STA-449 F3, NETZSCH, Germany) instrument with 20 mg of spent sample loading. The measurements were done under air flow rate of 20 cm3 min−1 at a temperature ramping rate of 5 °C min−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 BET surface area-pore size distribution Nitrogen physisorption isotherms and pore size distribution of Al-15Sb, Al-B-Sb and Al-15B samples are presented in Fig. 1 . Type-IV isotherms with H2 hysteresis loop [11] for all the studied samples were observed in Fig. 1a. Among the studied catalysts, Al-15B showed highest BET surface area of 290 m2 g−1. The decreasing order of measured BET surface area is as follows: Al-B (290 m2 g−1) > Al-B-5Sb (250 m2 g−1) > Al-B-10Sb (220 m2 g−1) > Al-15Sb (196 m2 g−1) > Al (160 m2 g−1). On the contrary Al-B catalyst prepared by impregnation method showed decreasing trend in the BET surface area with B loading from 10 to 30 wt.% [12]. Layered-slabs were observed for our synthesized Al-15B sample through HR-TEM analysis (Fig. 3) and this could be the reason for its high absorption capacity for adsorbate N2. Fig. 1b presents the pores size distribution of Al-15Sb, Al-B-Sb and Al-15B samples. It is clear from the results that all the studied samples mainly displayed pores in meso range (>2–6 nm) with minor portion of micropores (≤2 nm). Al alone showed an average mesopore diameter of 7nm. However, Al-15B sample displayed an average mesopore diameter of 6.5nm. Further, Al-15Sb sample exhibited narrow sized mesopores with an average pore size of 4.5nm. The decreasing order of total pore volume is as follows: Al-15B (0.50 cc g−1) > Al-B-5Sb (0.43 cc g−1) > Al-B-10Sb (0.36 cc g−1) > Al-15Sb (0.18 cc g−1) > Al (0.13 cc g−1). The significant increase in the pore volume of Al-15B sample over Al suggests that B acts as a pore-forming agent by suppressing the driving force of Al densification without affecting the connections of neighboring grains. On the other hand, Sb addition to Al does not improve the pore volume as high as B addition to Al. It might be associated with its bigger atomic radii. The BET/pore size results indicate that the pore structure is intact with addition of B or Sb to Al. 3.2 XPS analysis Fig. 2 a presents Sb3d and O1s XPS analysis results of Al-15Sb and Al-B-Sb samples. After subtracting Sb 3d5/2 signal from O1s, the Shirley deconvolution generated two signals at binding energy (BE) of 531.0 and 532.5 eV. The earlier signal can be related to oxygen (O−2) present in the oxide lattice and the later one ascribed to the non-lattice oxygen (O−) species in the oxide system. The Shirley deconvolution of Sb 3d was based on the signal ratio of 2:3 between Sb 3d3/2 and Sb 3d5/2. All the studied catalysts principally showed the presence of Sb4+ species with minor portion of Sb5+ and Sb3+ species at BE of 540.0, 541.0 and 538.5eV respectively. Nilsson et al. reported Sb 3d 3/2 BE at 540.4eV for Sb2O4, 540.8 eV for Sb2O5 and 539.0 eV for Sb2O3 [13]. The B1s XPS spectra are presented in Fig.2b. The XPS signals corresponds to B were observed at 192.5 eV attributed to B3+ ions in B2O3. XPS analysis of Al 2p in Al shows band at BE of 74.0 eV ascribed to Al3+ ions in Al2O3 [12]. Addition of B or Sb to Al slightly shifted the Al 2p BE to higher side and observed at 74.5–75.0 eV. Similar shift in the BE to higher side was observed by Colorio et al in B impregnated Al samples [12]. The XPS results indicate the primary presence of Al2O3, B2O3 and Sb2O4 species on the surface of the studied catalysts. The surface concentrations of Al, B and Sb species are presented in Table 1 . Greater surface content of Al was observed in B loaded sample compared to Sb loaded one at 15 mol.% of their loadings in Al. The results obtained for Sb (Table 1) content clearly suggests the primary presence of Sb4+ surface species (Sb2O4) in Al-B-Sb and Al-15Sb samples. 3.3 TEM studies Slab and worm like particle morphologies were observed for Al in Al-15Sb, Al-B-5Sb samples are associated with Al-O-Al links. Fig. 3 presents TEM and HR-TEM images for Al-B-5Sb and Al-15Sb samples. Fig. 3a TEM image clearly demonstrates homogeneous deposition of Sb particles on alumina slabs in Al-B-5Sb sample. The HR-TEM image of the same sample presented as Fig. 3b. The established d-spacing of 2.39 Å in Fig. 3b corresponds to (311) plane of γ-Al2O3 and other d-spacing of 3.23 Å corresponds to the (222) plane of Sb2O3. Principally slab type Al2O3 particles were observed with minor portion of worm like Al2O3 in Al-B-5Sb sample. However, majorly worm like Al2O3 (image Fig. 3d) was existed in Al-15Sb sample. The HR-TEM image of Al-15Sb in Fig.3e clearly demonstrates the Sb2O3 distribution in worm like Al2O3. The Sb particles were found to be spherical in shape with an average diameter less than 4nm in both the samples. The parallel beam EDS analysis of Al-B-5Sb and Al-15Sb samples were presented in Fig.3c and f respectively, revealed the presence of Al, B and Al, Sb elements.The layered slabs of Al clearly demonstrates that B addition suppresses densification of Al without affecting the connections of neighboring grains. 3.4 XRD studies X-ray diffractograms of Al, Al-15B, Al-B-Sb and Al-15Sb samples are presented in Fig. 4 . Alumina exhibited X-ray signals about the X-ray angle of 32.5, 37.5, 44.0, 60.0 and 66.0° are corresponds to γ-Al2O3 phase. All the other samples also exhibited X-ray signals corresponding to γ-Al2O3 phase. However, these signals were slightly shifted to lower side of X-ray angle. These shifts in the X-ray signal might be due to Al lattice distortions caused by B or Sb addition to it. X-ray signals appeared at X-ray angle of 54.0, 79.0 and 82.5° might be associated with alumina oxide before γ-Al2O3 formation. Further, no crystallite phases related to B and Sb was observed in the studied samples. The results indicate that small sized (<4nm) B or Sb crystallites possibly existed in these samples in line with TEM analysis. It is well known that Al-B bimetallic crystallite phases will appeared above 900 °C calcination temperatures [14]. Moreover, crystalline AlSbO4 phases were also observed above 700 °C calcination temperatures [15]. 3.5 NH3-TPD-mass-spectral analysis Ammonia TPD with mass spectral analysis of desorbed products from Al, Al-15B, Al-15Sb and Al-B-Sb samples are presented in Fig. 5 . The mass ions input at m/z = 17 is allotted for ammonia and the corresponding mass results presented in Fig. 5a. All the studied samples have displayed two distinct desorption peaks for ammonia. However, the peak desorption temperatures and relative amount of desorbed ammonia were varied from sample to sample. The Al sample showed ammonia desorption peaks with temperature maxima (Tmax) at 165 and 260 °C. Whereas, Al-15B and Al-B-5Sb exhibited ammonia desorption peaks at Tmax of 145 and 245 °C. However, Al-15Sb and Al-B-10Sb samples exhibited ammonia desertion peaks at Tmax of 115 and 245 °C. The results indicate that acid sites of weak and moderate strength are present in all the studied samples. Addition of 15 mol.% of Sb to Al (Al-15Sb sample) resulted in the reduction of acid strength of weak sites. Further, moderate acid site density was decreased in Al-15Sb and Al-B-10Sb samples. Essentially, B addition to Al enhanced the acid sites of weak and moderate strength. Small amount of Sb (5mol.%) addition to Al-15B slightly alter the weak and moderate acid site density. The mass spectral analysis of m/z = 16 is allotted for partially dehydrogenated ammonia species (-NH2) and the results are presented in Fig. 5b. A single desorption peak was observed at Tmax of 165, 145 and 115 °C for Al, Al-15B and Al-15Sb samples, respectively. It seems the acid sites of weak strength are performing desorption of ammonia as well as partially dehydrogenated ammonia in these samples as the desorption peak of –NH2 was observed at the identical Tmax of desorption of ammonia. The degraded products of –NH2 on V-Sb-W-Al-O catalyst was reported to produce H2O and N2. Further, nitrogen interaction with oxygen (surface/lattice) present in the catalyst gives rise to other –NH2 degraded products such as N2O and NO [14]. In the present study m/z = 18 (H2O) mass spectral analysis results are reported in Fig. 5c. All the studied catalysts showed a single desorption peak around Tmax 250 °C for H2O. This might be associated with surface and or lattice oxygen interacted with ammonia decomposed hydrogen and produced H2O [16]. Furthermore, to identify the differences between the types of acid sites on these catalysts the mass spectral analysis results of the formation of N2O and NO are presented in Fig. 5d and e, respectively. Almost no N2O formation was observed on Al. Relatively very low N2O desorption peak was observed on Al-15B sample in the temperature range of 200–250 °C compared to Al-B-Sb and Al-15Sb samples. Interestingly, a single desorption peak of N2O at Tmax 425 °C was observed for Al-B-5Sb. Whereas, N2O desorption peak was observed at Tmax 325 °C for Al-B-10Sb sample. Further, Al-15Sb showed a major N2O desorption peak at 260 °C. The major desorption peak of N2O shifted to lower temperature from 5%Sb (425 °C) to 10%Sb (325 °C) to 15%Sb (260 °C) loading in Al. The results indicate that easy formation of N2O was observed with gradual increase in the Sb loading in these samples. Hence the available surface or lattice oxygen on the Sb loaded catalysts can play a role in the styrene formation. Fig. 5e illustrates the mass spectral analysis results for desorption of NO (m/z = 30) on Al, Al-15B, Al-B-Sb and Al-15Sb samples. It is well known that NO formation is relatively difficult compared to N2O as ammonia decomposition lead to atomic N and quickly converts in to N2 molecule on V-Sb-W-Al-O surface [16]. Almost no nitric oxide desorption was observed on Al and Al-15B samples. On the other hand, Al-15Sb showed a single desorption peak for NO in the temperature range of 100–200 °C. However, Al-B-5Sb sample desorbed relatively high amount of NO compared to Al-B-10Sb and Al-15Sb samples in the temperature range of 100–200 °C. The results indicate that the acid sites generated by Sb in Al-B-Sb samples are capable of degrading –NH2 into NO. The total acidity calculated from NH3-TPD-TCD analysis of all the studied samples are presented in Table 2 . Among the studied catalysts, Al-15B displayed maximum total acidity of 480 μmol g−1 followed by Al-B-5Sb with 450 μmol g−1. The NH3-TPD-mass spectral analysis results are leading to draw the following conclusions regarding the acidity of the Al, Al-15B, Al-15Sb and Al-B-Sb samples. 1) B addition to alumina enhanced the acid sites of weak and moderate strength. 2) Sb addition to alumina decreases the strength of weak acid sites. 3) Al and Al-15B acid sites have the tendency to interact with ammonia decomposed hydrogen and produced H2O. 4) Sb acid sites are mainly contributed to the formation of N2O and NO in Al-15Sb and Al-B-Sb samples. 5) Small amount of Sb (up to 5 mol.%) addition to Al-15B exhibits acid sites of Al-B and Sb species. 3.6 Spent catalyst TG-DTG analysis The TG-DTG analysis of Al-15B and Al-B-5Sb catalysts spent for 60 h in ODH of EB to styrene is presented in Fig. 6 . The coke formed on these catalysts oxidized in two stages. The first exothermic emission of carbon oxides took place at 225 °C and the later emission occurred at 405 °C with weight loss ratio of 1:2 respectively. The total amount of coke in the form of carbon oxides observed for Al-B-5Sb was 6.5 wt.% and it was slightly higher for Al-15B (7.5 wt.%) catalysts after 60h of reaction. The results suggest that coke deposition reduced on these catalysts compared to reported alumina (10–37 wt.%) studied in the ODH of EB to styrene for 60 h [5]. The decreased coke deposition is associated with its oxidation by water stream used in the reaction. 3.7 Optimization of reaction parameters 3.7.1 Reaction temperature The catalytic activity of Al-15B catalyst in EB ODH to styrene was tested at three different temperatures (450, 475 and 500 °C) and the results are presented in Fig. 7 a. At 450 °C, EB conversion of 40% with 86% styrene selectivity was observed on this catalyst. The conversion was increased with increase in the reaction temperature and reached to a maximum value of 50% at 500 °C. However, at 500 °C, styrene selectivity was decreased to 84%. Further, maximum styrene selectivity of 94% with 46% of EB conversion was observed at 475 °C. Hence, the optimum reaction temperature in terms of styrene selectivity found to be at 475 °C on Al-15B catalyst. Side reactions are favorable at lower reaction temperatures (450 °C) led to other products (methane, ethane, ethylene, benzene and toluene) formation. On the other hand, Oxygen conversion and carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide (COx) selectivity was increased with increase in the reaction temperature. The results in Fig. 7a indicate that, at higher reaction temperatures (500 °C) coke formation was intensified through the decomposition of reaction products on Al-15B catalyst. At 475 °C, 36% of EB conversion with 83% styrene selectivity was observed by Nederlof et al. [5] on alumina calcined at 600 °C. At 475 °C, our lab synthesized Al2O3 showed 32% of EB conversion with 65% styrene selectivity. In addition, 20% other products with 15% COx selectivity was observed on alumina under studied reaction conditions. Boron impregnated Al2O3 catalysts were tested for EB ODH to styrene. However, the impregnated catalyst showed only 80–85% of styrene selectivity [17]. Further, Kania et al. [18] reported ODH of EB to styrene on modified alumina with CrO3 and Fe2O3 at 520 °C with 1:2.7 EB to air mole ratio and 10 g.h.mol−1 contact time. The authors observed 38–40% EB conversion with 78-80% styrene selectivity. Compared to literature Al-B catalysts showed higher selectiviy to styrene under studied reaction conditions. 3.7.2 Influence of contact time with respect to EB Fig. 7b shows the influence of EB contact time on EB conversion and styrene selectivity using Al-15B catalyst at 475 °C. At lower contact time (0.25 g.s/cm3), 44% of EB conversion with 85% styrene selectivity was observed on this catalyst. On the other hand, 50% of EB conversion with 75–80% of styrene selectivity was obtained at higher contact times (0.85 and 1.2 g.s/cm3). However, 46% of EB conversion with maximum styrene selectivity of 94% was observed at moderate contact time (0.54 g.s/cm3). Furthermore, reasonable oxygen conversion with lower COx and other product formation was observed at moderate EB contact time. Hence, the moderate EB contact time has been selected for further catalytic activity studies. 3.8 Influence of Sb content Influence of Sb content in Al and Al-15B on EB conversion and styrene selectivity was studied at 475 °C with 0.54 g.s/cm3 EB contact time. The results are presented in Fig. 8 a. Al-15Sb catalyst exhibited 38% EB conversion with 76% styrene selectivity. Greater EB conversion (52.5%) with 92% styrene selectivity was obtained on Al-B-5Sb catalyst. Both EB conversion (50%) and styrene selectivity (88%) was decreased on Al-B-10Sb compared to Al-B-5Sb catalyst. Among the studied catalysts the decreasing order of EB conversion is as follows: Al-B-5Sb (52.5%) > Al-B-10Sb (50%) > Al-15B (46%) > Al-15Sb (38%). Addition of Sb to Al (Al-15Sb catalyst) produced 10% other products with 14% COx selectivity. However, the COx and other product formation was low (<5%) on Al-B-5Sb catalyst. The improved other product and COx formation on Al-B-10Sb and Al-15Sb over Al-B-5Sb might be associated with the acid sites contributed to N2O formation. The easy formation of N2O during the NH3-TPD-mass analysis was observed due to available lattice or surface oxygen in these catalysts. During the reaction, these acid sites were contributing to EB degraded products. Whereas the acid sites related to NO formation in Al-B-5Sb improved the EB conversion. Homogeneous deposition of antimony oxide in Al-B-5Sb was behaving differently in terms of surface acidity than Al-B-10Sb and Al-15Sb. The correlation between ammonia up take per meter square of alumina and styrene yield is presented in Fig. 8b. It is obvious from the results that the greater styrene yield of 48.8% was obtained on Al-B-5Sb followed by Al-B-10Sb (44%) catalysts. It is associated with greater ammonia uptake per meter squre of sample (Table 2). The greater styrene yield on Al-15B (43%) compared to Al (18%) is associated with increased number of acid centers with weak and strong strength due to B addition. Similar results were reported by Colorio et al. [12] for alumina-boria catalysts used in the partial oxidation of ethane to ethylene and acetaldehyde reaction. According to the authors acidity increases with boron loading in alumina and improves the catalytic activity. On the other hand, alumina texture also played a significant role in the formation of styrene. Alumina layered slabs enhanced the styrene yield to 43% and Sb particles deposited on this slabs further improved the styrene yield to 48.8%. Whereas, Sb particles deposited in worm like alumina in Al-15Sb showed lower styrene yield (26.5%) compared to Al-15B and Al-B-Sb catalysts. 3.9 Time on stream studies Long term stability of Al-15B and Al-B-5Sb catalysts are tested for 60h in ODH of EB to styrene at 475 °C with 0.54 g.s/cm3 contact time. It is obvious from the Fig. 9 that the catalytic activities are quite consistent for 60h under studied reaction conditions. Al-15B showed about 46% of EB conversion with 94% of styrene selectivity. On the other hand, Al-B-5Sb exhibited an average EB conversion of 52.5% with 92% of styrene selectivity. The results suggest that the deactivation of Al-15B catalyst is slow under the studied reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions The catalytic performance of alumina in ODH of EB to styrene can be improved by the promotion with B and Sb. Boron addition to alumina using sol-gel method eventually enhanced the BET surface area and acid site density of Al-15B catalyst. Weak and moderate acid sites on the surface of Al-15B catalyst were responsible for high selectivity to styrene (94%). Highest yield of styrene (48.8%) was achieved at Al-B-5Sb composition. It is associated with increased number of acid sites per m2 of the surface of this composition. Steady catalytic activity was observed for 60 h of continuous operation with 52.5% EB conversion, 92% styrene selectivity on Al-B-5Sb catalyst. Hence, Al-B-5Sb is a promising catalyst and has the potential to be employed in the bulk styrene production from ODH of EB. coredata.dc:description: Alumina (Al), alumina-boron (Al-15B), alumina-boron-antimony (Al-B-Sb) and alumina-antimony (Al-15Sb) catalysts were synthesized by sol-gel method using ethanol as a solvent and ammonia gas as a gel forming agent. These catalysts were studied for the dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene (EB) to styrene in the presence of oxygen and steam. The reaction was carried out in the temperature range of 450-500 °C with EB contact time 0.54 gcat.s/cm3. The synthesized catalysts were characterized by using N2-physisorption, XRD, XPS, TEM-HRTEM-EDS and NH3-TPD-mass spectral analysis techniques. At 475 °C, only 58% of styrene selectivity with 32% of EB conversion was observed on Al. Addition of 15 mol.% of B to Al significantly enhanced the selectivity of styrene to 94% with 46% EB conversion at 475 °C. Addition of 15 mol.% Sb to Al reduced the EB conversion (38%) and styrene selectivity (75%) compared to Al-15B catalyst. Interestingly, small amount of Sb (5 mol.%) addition to Al-B improved the EB conversion to 52.5% with 92% of styrene selectivity at 475 °C. The acid sites of weak and moderate strength were increased in Al-15B catalyst compared to Al. Boron played a dual role as Al densification suppressing agent and to some extent deposited on the surface of Al which improved the styrene selectivity. However, small amount of Sb addition to Al-15B not only retained weak and moderate strength acid sites of Al-B but also generated acid sites of Sb which led to the formation of N2O and NO during NH3-TPD-mass analysis. Hence, the styrene yield (48.8%) was improved on Al-B-5Sb compared to Al-15B catalyst (43%). It is noteworthy that Al-15B and Al-B-5Sb catalysts were stable for more than 60h of reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Ethyl benzene oxidative dehydrogenation to styrene on Al-B and Al-B-Sb catalysts
